text: thousands of people are still seeking
refuge in United Nations compound in the
capital the government has asked people
to return home and while some have
heeded the call others remained cautious
although calm is returning to Juba the
UN says there was fighting early on
Wednesday morning in turret and more
than a thousand civilians have sought
refuge in a UN compound there there are
also clashes in bor in the capital
people in the UN compounds have been
speaking about what happened to them he
can't find a lot of bodies all other
place so I had my cousin over there it's
not even being buried right now and I
had a large gets a lot of friend that
I've been there with them for couple
days now they are all gone I don't know
why people they don't learn from
mistakes I don't know they don't learn
from some other leaders line and for
Mandela the government suspects the
former vice president who was dismissed
in July of being behind the violence and
accusation he strongly denies what
happened was that the soul is in the
presidential guards division they fought
among themselves and and this was
useless self Akira added to say we were
plotting now though President Salva Kiir
says he's ready to talk to his former
deputy the United Nations played a key
role in the creation of an independent
South Sudan two years ago and now it's
worried about a return to conflict and
deeply concerned about the current
situation in South Sudan I spoke to
President Salva Kiir yesterday morning
urging him to do everything possible he
can to end the violence and to ensure
our respect for human rights and the
rule of law I also impressed on him a
tally to resume dialogue with a
political opposition I welcome the
reports this morning that President
Salva Kiir is willing to enter into such
talks as well as the United Nations
regional powers are also watch
in the situation closely knowing that
South Sudan cannot afford another Civil
War Damien Zane BBC News
